title: Senso-ji Temple
content: Tokyo’s oldest and most famous Buddhist temple. Features the Kaminarimon gate, a massive red lantern, and the lively Nakamise shopping street.

title: Meiji Shrine
content: Shinto shrine dedicated to Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken. Surrounded by dense forest, perfect for peaceful walks and cultural ceremonies.

title: Zojo-ji Temple
content: Located near Tokyo Tower, Zojo-ji is a historic Buddhist temple with a dramatic skyline view. Houses the graves of Tokugawa shoguns.

title: Gotokuji Temple
content: Famous as the origin of the 'maneki-neko' (beckoning cat). A peaceful temple filled with hundreds of cat statues.

title: Nezu Shrine
content: One of Tokyo’s oldest shrines, known for its beautiful azalea garden and long line of red torii gates.

title: Tokyo Skytree
content: Tallest structure in Japan. Offers 360-degree views from two observation decks. Includes a massive shopping center and aquarium.

title: Shibuya Sky
content: Modern rooftop observatory on top of Shibuya Scramble Square. Open-air space perfect for sunset views and photos.

title: Tokyo Tower
content: Iconic red-and-white tower inspired by the Eiffel Tower. Offers panoramic views and houses a small theme park and aquarium.

title: Roppongi Hills Observation Deck
content: Located in the Mori Tower. Offers city views, art exhibitions, and access to the Mori Art Museum.

title: Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden
content: Massive garden blending traditional Japanese, English, and French styles. Stunning in cherry blossom season.

title: Asakusa
content: Old-town charm with Senso-ji Temple, rickshaws, street food, and the Sumida River. A must-visit for traditional Tokyo.

title: Shibuya
content: Youth culture hub with fashion, nightlife, and the world-famous Shibuya Scramble Crossing.

title: Harajuku
content: Vibrant center of street fashion and trends. Visit Takeshita Street for the full experience.

title: Daikanyama
content: Trendy neighborhood with stylish cafes, indie bookstores, and peaceful residential streets.

title: Shimokitazawa
content: Laid-back district popular for vintage shops, live music, and alternative culture. Great for exploring on foot.

title: Kagurazaka
content: Old geisha district now known for its French influence, cobbled alleys, and mix of traditional and modern restaurants.

title: Cultural Tips for Travelers
content: Bow politely when greeting. Remove shoes when entering homes or traditional spaces. Don’t speak loudly on trains or in temples.

title: Train Etiquette in Tokyo
content: Keep phones silent. Don’t eat or talk loudly. Priority seating is for the elderly, pregnant women, and disabled passengers.

title: Onsen Etiquette
content: Wash thoroughly before entering the bath. Don’t bring towels into the water. Tattoos may not be allowed in some baths.

title: Dining Etiquette in Tokyo
content: Slurping noodles is polite. Don’t pass food with chopsticks. Say 'Itadakimasu' before eating and 'Gochisousama' after.

title: Tokyo Station
content: Historic train station with red-brick facade, underground shopping malls, and access to bullet trains (Shinkansen).

title: Akihabara
content: Electronics, anime, and gaming capital of Tokyo. Explore maid cafes, retro games, and otaku culture.

title: Ginza
content: Luxury shopping district with flagship stores, high-end boutiques, and Michelin-starred restaurants.

title: Kanda Myōjin Shrine
content: An important Edo-period shrine near Akihabara, Kanda Myōjin is known for its vibrant festivals and popularity among tech workers and anime fans who come to pray for luck.

title: Tenno-ji Temple
content: A quiet, lesser-known temple in the traditional neighborhood of Yanaka. Offers a glimpse of pre-war Tokyo and peaceful cemetery grounds.

title: Arakawa Yūen Amusement Park
content: A small retro amusement park with a Ferris wheel offering charming views over the Sumida River. Great for families and nostalgic vibes.

title: Hie Shrine
content: Known for its tunnel of red torii gates and annual Sanno Festival. A peaceful spiritual site in the middle of the business district.

title: Sumida Park
content: A riverside park perfect for cherry blossom season, with views of Tokyo Skytree across the Sumida River. Popular for hanami picnics.

title: Rikugien Garden
content: A classical Japanese landscape garden with miniature hills, bridges, and seasonal illumination events.

title: Kappabashi Street
content: Famous for selling everything related to cooking: knives, fake food displays, dishes, and more. A paradise for chefs and restaurant owners.

title: Kagurazaka Backstreets
content: Explore cobbled alleys, hidden ryotei (traditional restaurants), and former geisha houses. Offers a mix of Edo-period charm and French expat culture.

title: Oshino Hakkai
content: A historic village with clear spring ponds and views of Mt. Fuji. Ideal for day trips from Tokyo.

title: Toyosu Market
content: The new home of the famous Tsukiji fish auction. Offers sushi breakfasts, seafood experiences, and an observation deck over the trading floor.

title: teamLab Planets
content: Immersive digital art museum where you walk through water, mirrors, and light shows. A truly futuristic Tokyo experience.

title: Ebisu Yokocho
content: A maze of izakayas (Japanese pubs) with lanterns, small plates, and local drinks. Lively and authentic nightlife in tight alleyways.

title: Koenji
content: An alternative music and punk scene hub. Packed with vintage clothing stores, underground venues, and a strong counterculture vibe.

title: Tsukiji Outer Market
content: Still home to fresh sushi, kitchen gear, street food, and wasabi root despite the auction moving to Toyosu.

title: Otemachi Onsen
content: Modern spa facility using natural hot spring water beneath Tokyo’s financial district. Great for a relaxing midday break.

title: Meguro River
content: Picturesque river lined with sakura trees, boutique cafes, and perfect cherry blossom views in spring.

title: Mount Takao
content: Hiking destination one hour from Shinjuku. Offers forest trails, a monkey park, temples, and panoramic views of Mt. Fuji on clear days.

title: Ikebukuro
content: Lively entertainment district with Sunshine City, Pokémon Center Mega Tokyo, and one of the busiest train stations in the world.

title: Komeda’s Coffee
content: Beloved Nagoya-origin coffee chain offering classic breakfasts, cozy booths, and the famous ‘Shiro Noir’ dessert.

title: Yoyogi Park
content: Large urban park near Harajuku with open lawns, fountains, and drum circle gatherings on weekends.

title: Kabukiza Theatre
content: Watch traditional Kabuki performances in a historic building. Single-act tickets available for beginners.

title: Sumo Museum
content: Located near the Ryogoku Kokugikan arena. Learn about sumo history, top-ranked wrestlers, and traditional rituals.

title: Nippori Fabric Town
content: A long street of shops selling textiles, buttons, and handmade crafts. Popular with designers and DIY crafters.

title: Shibamata Taishakuten
content: A nostalgic town full of Showa-era vibes. Visit the wooden Taishakuten Temple and traditional candy shops nearby.

title: Public Bathhouses in Tokyo
content: Try local sento (public baths) like Daikokuyu or Thermae-Yu. Clean your body first, don’t wear swimsuits, and enjoy the soak!
